ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Influence of temperature on the electric, dielectric and AC conductivity properties of nano-crystalline zinc substituted cobalt ferrite synthesized by solution combustion technique

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Materials Science Research Laboratory, Department of Physics

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para:
Cobalt–zinc nanoferrites with formulae Co
$$_{1-x}$$
1 - x
Zn
$$_{x}$$
x
Fe
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{4}$$
4
, where x = 0.0, 0.1, 0.2 and 0.3, have been synthesized by solution combustion technique. The variation of DC resistivity with temperature shows the semiconducting behavior of all nanoferrites. The dielectric properties such as dielectric constant (
$$\varepsilon $$
ε
’) and dielectric loss tangent (tan
$$\delta )$$
δ )
are investigated as a function of temperature and frequency. Dielectric constant and loss tangent are found to be increasing with an increase in temperature while with an increase in frequency both,
$$\varepsilon $$
ε
’ and tan
$$\delta $$
δ
, are found to be decreasing. The dielectric properties have been explained on the basis of space charge polarization according to Maxwell–Wagner’s two-layer model and the hopping of charge between Fe
$$^{2+}$$
2 +
and Fe
$$^{3+}$$
3 +
. Further, a very high value of dielectric constant and a low value of tan
$$\delta $$
δ
are the prime achievements of the present work. The AC electrical conductivity (
$$\sigma _\mathrm{AC})$$
σ AC
)
is studied as a function of temperature as well as frequency and
$$\sigma _\mathrm{AC}$$
σ AC
is observed to be increasing with the increase in temperature and frequency.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Ferrites forming a group of semiconducting materials are of great technological importance. Nanocrystalline materials are the centre of attention due to their tremendous applications and interesting properties. The properties of nanomaterials are amazingly different than that of their bulk counterpart. The interest in the ferrite nanoparticles is because of their important physical and chemical properties for various technological applications such as high density magnetic storage, bubble devices, electronic communication devices, sensors, magnetically guided drug delivery [1]. The high resistivity of ferrites makes them suitable for microwave applications and with the tremendous increase in the development of microwave and millimeter wave-based communication technologies, the production of dielectric resonators has emerged as one of the most rapid growth areas in electro-ceramic manufacturing. Recently, much attention has been directed towards the development of materials with improved microwave properties for wireless communication technologies such as mobile phones, intelligent transport systems (ITS), ultrahigh-speed wireless LAN, and satellite broadcasting. The dielectric properties of ferrites depend upon several factors such as method of preparation, chemical composition and grain structure or size. Further, temperature, composition and frequency dependent dielectric studies of ferrites give valuable information about conduction phenomenon in the ferrites based on localized electric charge carriers [2]. Cobalt ferrite is a hard magnetic material and attracted considerable attention of the scientific community [1]. Further, the cobalt ferrite possesses an inverse spinel structure and exhibits high DC electrical resistivity, positive anisotropy constant, large magnetostriction, good chemical stability and mechanical hardness [3]. As the properties of ferrites are influenced by synthesizing techniques thus, many researchers have prepared cobalt and substituted cobalt ferrites by sol-gel method [1, 4], ceramic method [5, 6], hydrothermal technique [7], co-precipitation method [8, 9], forced hydrolysis method [10], solid state reaction technique [11], citrate precursor technique [12], chemical solution technique [13], solvo-thermal technique [14], combustion method [15, 16]. Further, due to the technological applications of cobalt and substituted cobalt ferrites many workers have investigated only the magnetic properties of cobalt ferrites [17, 18] and substituted cobalt ferrites [4, 5, 7–12, 14–16] but a very little literature is available on the electric and dielectric study of cobalt and substituted cobalt ferrites [1, 6, 13, 19–21]. Thus, in the present work we are reporting the temperature dependent electric, dielectric and AC conductivity study of zinc substituted cobalt ferrite.

Section2.Heading: Structural study
Section2.Para:
Figure 1 shows the X-ray patterns of Co
$$_{1-x}$$
1 - x
Zn
$$_{x}$$
x
Fe
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{4}$$
4
nanoferrites, which indicates a typical cubic spinel structure. The broad peaks indicate that the mean crystallite size of prepared samples is in the nanometer range. The crystallite size of the samples was calculated by using the Scherrer formula [23]. 3
$$\begin{aligned} D=\frac{0.9 \lambda }{\beta \cos \theta } \end{aligned}$$
D =
0.9 λ
β cos θ
where D is crystallite size,
$$\beta $$
β
is full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the (311) peak,
$$\lambda $$
λ
is X-ray wavelength, and
$$\theta $$
θ
is diffraction angle. Average crystallite size of the cobalt nanoferrite was found to be decreasing with the increasing substitution of zinc ions. Average crystallite size for all samples was obtained as 29, 25, 24, 22 and 21 nm for x = 0.0, x = 0.1, x = 0.2, x = 0.3, and x = 0.4 respectively. The crystallite size was found to be decreasing with the increasing substitution of zinc ions. The lattice parameter ‘a’ is found to be increasing with the increase in zinc content and is 8.377, 8.380, 8.385, 8.390 and 8.396 Å for x = 0.0, x = 0.1, x = 0.2, x = 0.3, and x = 0.4 respectively. The increase in ‘a’ with increase in zinc content is due to the fact that the radius of cobalt ions is smaller than that of zinc ions. Therefore as the concentration of Zn ions increases the lattice parameter also increases [24].

Section2.Heading: Variation of DC resistivity with temperature
Section2.Para:
Figure 2 shows the variation in DC resistivity with temperature. The DC resistivity is observed to be decreasing with an increase in temperature and this variation is in accordance with the Arrhenius equation [25]. 4
$$\begin{aligned} \rho =\rho _0 \exp \frac{\Delta E}{kT} \end{aligned}$$
ρ =
ρ 0
exp
Δ E
k T
where
$$\rho _{0}$$
ρ 0
is pre-exponential factor, k is Boltzman constant, T is absolute temperature and
$$\Delta $$
Δ
E is activation energy. This decrease in resistivity with an increase in temperature shows the semiconducting nature of cobalt-zinc nanoferrites. The resistivity decreases with an increase in temperature because an increase in temperature will increase the drift mobility of the charge carriers; since increase in temperature will help the bound charges to participate in the conduction process [26]. Further, it is evident from the figure that DC resistivity is increasing with the increasing content of zinc ions. As Zn
$$^{2+}$$
2 +
ions strongly prefers to occupy A-sites, while cobalt ions partially occupy A-sites and B-sites. Thus, when Zn
$$^{2+}$$
2 +
ions increases at A-sites then some of the Fe-ions from B-sites will migrate towards the A-sites as a result the number of Fe
$$^{2+ }$$
2 +
and Fe
$$^{3+}$$
3 +
ions at B-sites, which are responsible for electrical conduction in ferrites, will decrease. The activation energies are calculated from the slopes of the paramagnetic and ferrimagnetic region according to the relation 5
$$\begin{aligned} \Delta E=[0.198 \times 10^{-3}\times d( {\log \rho })]/d( {1/T}) \end{aligned}$$
Δ E = [ 0.198 ×
10
- 3
× d
(
log ρ
)
] / d
(
1 / T
)
The calculated values are given in Table 1. From Table it is evident that the value of activation energy in the ferrimagnetic region is lower than that of the paramagnetic region. The lower activation energy in the ferrimagnetic region is attributed to the magnetic disordering due to the decrease in concentration of current carriers, while the change in activation energy is attributed to the change in conduction mechanism [27].

Section2.Heading: Variation of dielectric constant
Section2.Para:
Figure 3a, b are showing the variation of dielectric constant (
$$\varepsilon ^{\prime } $$
ε ′
) with temperature at different frequencies. It is evident from the results that dielectric constant is increasing with an increase in temperature. This temperature dependence of dielectric constant (
$$\varepsilon ^{\prime })$$
ε ′
)
can be explained on the basis of polarization effect. In general, the dielectric constant is because of the four types of polarizations viz. dipolar polarization, electronic polarization, ionic polarization and interfacial polarization. At low frequencies, interfacial polarization and dipolar polarization are known to play the most significant role and both of these polarizations are temperature dependent [26]. Interfacial polarizations are because of the buildup of charges at the grain boundary. An increase in temperature will enhance the electrical conductivity due to the enhancement in thermally activated drift mobility of the electric charge carriers thus, dielectric polarization increases resulting thereby in the increase of dielectric constant. Further, the results show that at all temperatures the dielectric constant is decreasing with an increase in frequency. The dielectric structure is composed of well conducting grains separated by the poorly conducting grain boundaries [28] and the electronic exchange between the Fe
$$^{2+}$$
2 +
and Fe
$$^{3+}$$
3 +
ions results in the local displacements of electrons along the direction of applied external field. These displacements determine the polarization as well as the dielectric properties. The observed decrease in dielectric constant with an increase in frequency is due to the fact that above certain frequency, the electronic exchange between the ferrous and ferric ions does not follow the applied field. Figure 4a, b are showing the variations of dielectric loss with temperature at different frequencies. The energy losses in the dielectrics are because of the electric conductivity of the materials and the relaxation effect to the orientation of the dipole. The increase in the dielectric loss with an increase in temperature shows that losses due to electrical conductivity are more profound than those due to the relaxation effects [29]. Further, the results indicate a maximum in dielectric loss and can be explained on the basis Koop’s model [30]. According to Koop’s model the solid is composed of grains and grain boundaries. The grains have low resistivity and large thickness while the grain boundaries have high resistivity and small thickness. Moreover, it was assumed that each of the grain and grain boundaries has its characteristic peak. Thus, the observed peak in the dielectric loss may be attributed to the contribution from the grain boundaries, which takes part in the conduction at low temperatures while the role of the grains can appear at higher temperatures [31]. Further, it is also evident from the results that at all temperatures the dielectric loss is decreasing with the increase in frequency. These results are in close agreement with Koop’s phenomenological model [26]. Further there is a strong correlation between the conduction mechanism and dielectric polarization in ferrites. The conduction mechanism in ferrites is considered due to hopping of electrons between Fe
$$^{2+}$$
2 +
and Fe
$$^{3+}$$
3 +
ions. The dielectric loss (tan
$$\delta )$$
δ )
decreases rapidly in the low frequency region, while the rate of decrease is slow in high frequency region where it becomes almost frequency independent. Such a behavior can be explained on the basis that in low frequency region, which corresponds to low conductivity of grain boundary, more energy is required for electron exchange between Fe
$$^{2+}$$
2 +
and Fe
$$^{3+}$$
3 +
ions, as a result the loss is high. In high frequency region, which corresponds to high conductivity of grain, a small energy is required for electron transfer between theFe
$$^{2+}$$
2 +
/Fe
$$^{3+}$$
3 +
ions at the octahedral site [32]. As the dielectric loss arises if the polarization lags behind the applied altering field and is caused by the presence of impurities and structural inhomogeneities thus the low dielectric loss values obtained in the present work are therefore attributed to more structurally perfect and homogeneous ferrites processed by the solution combustion technique.

with temperature at different frequencies for Zn = 0.2 and Zn = 0.3 nanoferrites

Section2.Heading: Variation of AC conductivity
Section2.Para:
Figure 5a, b are showing the variations of AC conductivity with frequency at different temperatures. The plots for variations of AC electrical conductivity with frequency are observed to be almost linear confirming the polaron type conduction. The electrical conduction is because of the migration of ions and this ionic transport depends on the angular frequency. Thus, AC conductivity is proportional to the angular frequency confirming the linear nature [25]. In the present study it has been observed that the AC conductivity is increasing with an increase in frequency. The increase in AC conductivity with an applied field frequency can be explained on the basis that the pumping force of the applied field helps in transferring the charge carriers between the different localized states as well as liberate the trapped charges from the different trapping centers [22]. These charge carriers will take part in the conduction process all together with the electrons produced from the valence exchange between the different metal ions [33]. In other words, increase in frequency will increase the electron hopping frequency between the charge carriers resulting thereby in an increase in conductivity. Figure6a, b are showing the variation of AC electrical conductivity with temperature at different frequencies. It is observed that the conductivity is increasing with the increase in temperature and is due to the thermally enhanced drift mobility of charge carriers.
Fig. 5
a Variation of AC conductivity with frequency at different temperatures for Zn = 0.0 and Zn = 0.1 nanoferrites. b Variation of AC conductivity with frequency at different temperatures for Zn = 0.2 and Zn = 0.3 nanoferrites
Fig. 6
a Variation of AC conductivity with temperature at different frequencies for Zn = 0.0 and Zn = 0.1 nanoferrites. b Variation of AC conductivity with temperature at different frequencies for Zn = 0.2 and Zn = 0.3 nanoferrites

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para:
Nanosized zinc substituted cobalt ferrites are successfully synthesized by solution combustion technique. Zinc doping has resulted in an increase in lattice parameter and a decrease in particle size of cobalt nanoferrite. The room temperature resistivity is found to be of the order of 10
$$^{8} \quad \Omega $$
8
Ω
-cm and the same is observed to be decreasing with an increase in temperature. Frequency dependence of dielectric constant showed normal dielectric behavior and is in good agreement with Koop’s phenomenological theory of dielectric dispersion. AC conductivity as well as dielectric constant is found to increase with an increase in temperature which is due to thermally enhanced drift mobility of charge carriers. The very high values of dielectric constant and the low values of dielectric loss tangent are obtained in the present work which makes these nanoferrites very suitable for microwave applications.
